newsitem.title: USA: Producer prices up 0.2 percent in September.
newsitem.headline: Producer prices up 0.2 percent in September.

text.p: Producer prices advanced modestly in September, the Labour Department said Friday, as moderate increases in food and energy prices helped to restrain the overall rate of wholesale inflation.

The Labour Department said the Producer Price Index rose 0.2 percent last month, after rising 0.3 percent in August. Excluding food and energy prices, the "core rate" of inflation moved up 0.3 percent due in part to higher prices for passenger cars and light trucks.

Analysts said the report confirmed that inflation remained relatively tame at the wholesale level. "This tells us we've got moderate growth without inflation, so it confirms the status quo," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.
The inflation-sensitive 30-year U.S. Treasury bond gained half a point in price, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.85 percent from 6.89 percent late Thursday.
Economists surveyed by Reuters had forecast a rise of 0.3 percent in the PPI, with a gain of 0.2 percent in the core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices.
In August, the core PPI fell 0.1 percent.
Economists have become increasingly concerned that rising labour costs in a tightening job market could lead to a pickup in inflation in the months ahead.

So far, inflation data have suggested that businesses are reluctant to pass along higher labour costs in the form of price increases. Labour costs, however, have a far bigger impact on the Consumer Price Index, which is due next Wednesday, than on the Producer Price Index.
"The inflation story is going to be the Consumer Price Index," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co.

Friday's report showed that food prices rose 0.2 percent in September, compared with a jump of 1.0 percent a month before. Beef, veal and fruit prices rose, while pork, poultry, fish and vegetable prices fell.
Energy prices gained 0.2 percent, after rising 0.7 percent in August. The increase was paced by a 0.9 percent jump in gasoline and a gain of 2.0 percent in heating oil prices.
Passenger car prices jumped 1.2 percent in September, posting the biggest one-month gain since November 1993, when prices rose 1.3 percent. Tobacco product prices fell 1.0 percent.
Prices of intermediate goods -- those that require further processing -- rose 0.3 percent last month after increasing 0.2 percent in August.
